45. Some attempt to bring stories to life
by such strange means,
with various sundry elaborations,
that one guesses poorly at the meaning
whether or not one he already knew the story.
Here I offer an example,
Which was recounted by the poet Iacobo,
A poet from the City named after one of the Sirens.
right-middleHow some depict their histories strangely, and make them almost incomprehensible, as in an example by Sannazaro, Poet of Naples.

46. Founded by the Chalcidians or Cumaeans:
He explains in his Arcadia
how the shepherd Arcadians
on the feast day of Pales –being her subjects–
came together at her Temple
to make an offering on the smoking Altar,
but saw painted above the doorway
hills and forests, overgrown with flowers.
right-middleHere follows an example: a decorative painting in Pales’ Temple, to learn elaborations.

47. There one saw pastures in green fields
dotted with many flocks, accompanied by
about ten dogs, who acted as guards,
lest they scatter and become separated,
one saw their footsteps on the sand,
and some of the shepherds relieving
the stiff udders swollen with milk
and others shearing the curly fleeces.

48. There one saw some playing bagpipes,
others, while singing, appeared to wish
to imitate the sound with their voices.
There was above all else,
in the eyes of many with
with particular judicious art,
(welstandigen) a company of Nymphs,
quite naked, half-hidden by a chestnut bush.

49. These were looking at a ram before them
and laughing together joyfully,
for he stood there with great enjoyment
gnawing on a spray of oak leaves
he saw hanging before his eyes
and thus forgot, through such vain desire,
to graze on the green grass
and pleasant pastures at his feet.

50. In the midst there were four Satyrs,
with horns on their heads and Goats’ legs,
came softly through the branch of a mastic tree
reaching out from behind to seize them
